CORE TEAM

Falk Benke, CEO

Falk is the resident German, originally from Berlin. He came to Ghana in 2013 to work as a Teaching Fellow at the Meltwater Entrepreneurial School of Technology (MEST). Here, he got excited about entrepreneurship and decided to start his own company out of Ghana. In his freetime, he enjoys travelling West Africa and hanging out at the gym. His favourite Ghanaian dish is Red Red.

Gerald Pharin, CTO

Gerald spends his day with his newly-found girlfriend. There isn't a thing he could do without her. He likes to spend the weekend with his family and definitely loves to watch comic videos. When not working, you'll see him smiling most of the time behind his laptop - no one knows why. You should ask him when you do get a chance to do so.

Kingston Tagoe, CPO

After spending a couple of days at Aburi, Kingston found the perfect and breath-taking view which overlooks Accra and he often spends his weekend there to relax. He loves listening to stories about how the older folks lived pre-independence - and he plans on putting this into a book sometime in the future. After training as an Aerospace engineer, he pursued his passion in tech entreprenuership at MEST and now manages product development at Beam.

ADVISORS

Neal Hansch, Advisor

Neal has over fifteen years experience in venture capital, technology operations and investment banking. Most recently, he was a General Partner with Rustic Canyon Partners (RCP), an early-stage focused investment fund with $500MM under management. Neal does his best to disconnect from his digital devices by heading to the nearest body of water to enjoy some surfing, scuba diving, sailing or fishing.

Emmanuel Quartey, Advisor

Emmanuel is happiest when neck-deep in Photoshop files. Heâ€™s worked on the design and marketing teams of organizations both large and small, including SeeClickFix and the Yale Office of Public Affairs and Communications. He holds a BA in Architecture from Yale University, and can often be found reading or writing about comics, online communities, and the relationship between language and interfaces.
